newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada banks hit new highs on bond rally, buybacks.
newsitem.headline: Canada banks hit new highs on bond rally, buybacks.

text.p: Canadian bank stocks soared to new heights on the Toronto Stock Exchange on Friday, boosted by a surging bond market and recent share buybacks.
Shares in Canada's five biggest banks hit 52-week highs after tame U.S. inflation reports sparked a rally in North American debt markets.
Bank of Montreal was the heaviest trader, climbing 0.65 to 34.55 in early afternoon turnover of 2.7 million shares. The stock earlier reached a 52-week peak of 34.65.
"Generally speaking, bank stocks look like they are undervalued," said Nesbitt Burns Inc analyst Hugh Brown.
"If bond markets rally it makes them more undervalued and that's good," Brown said.
Canadian bonds strengthened with U.S. treasuries following the release of weaker-than-expected U.S. economic data which calmed fears of an imminent hike in U.S. interest rates.
Recent share buybacks have also spurred bank stocks to record highs.
Royal Bank of Canada was up 0.80 to 37 on 1.4 million shares after earlier reaching a new high of 37.20.
The country's biggest bank announced plans on Thursday for a massive share repurchase totalling about C$1.1 billion.
Royal Bank is the latest Canadian bank to plan a huge repurchase.

Toronto-Dominion Bank said in July that it planned to buy back up to 10 percent of its common shares. Last November, Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce launched a program to repurchase about five percent of its stock.
"Most banks in Canada are generating excess capital internally. There are various things you can do with it and one of them is share buybacks," Brown said.
The Royal Bank and TD repurchases are partly intended to offset the dilutive impact of recent acquisitions.
Bank of Montreal has bought back about five million shares in the current fiscal year ended October 31.

"If we reach a point where we think that we can't productively use all the shareholder equity in the bank, then we would obviously want to return that equity to our shareholders," said bank spokesman Joe Barbera.
Bank of Montreal's stock was up 0.60 at 34.50 after earlier reaching a new high of 34.65.
Bank of Nova Scotia said it has not made a major share buyback in recent years, due to the fact that its acquisitions have been small with little dilutive effect.
"This is something that we continually monitor and evaluate, but we don't have any immediate plans to do a buyback," said Scotiabank spokeswoman Shelley Jourard.
Bank of Nova Scotia's stock was up 1.15 at 36.20 after reaching a new peak of 36.25 earlier in the session.
Among the other bank stocks, CIBC climbed 0.55 to 47.65 following a high of 47.80. T-D Bank rose 0.35 to 27.30 after a 52-week record of 27.45.
National Bank of Canada, the country's sixth largest bank, also rose, but failed to set a new high. National's stock was up 0.10 at 11.65.
-- Darren Schuettler, Reuters Toronto (416) 941-8100
